content.description: Start as for Quincy Market. Climb easily up to the lip then start the hard leftward traverse on slopers across the lip. Go around the arete and continue up progressively easier climbing to the high point of the boulder, this shares a finish with Re-fresh. This route is defined by slopers and fairly good feet, so avoid the pump and enjoy the route.
content.location: On the boulder to the left as you cross the stone wall from the road. It's connected to the wall and is staring right at you. Start on easy flakes just left of stone wall, as for Quincy Market.

content.description: Sit start on the great hold on the right side of the "nose" and make a large move up to a jug, use a heel to keep your balance after this move. Then continue up the arete on easy holds until you have reached the height of the arete, then rock over onto the top of the rock and you are done. The top out of this route is at the same place as      Re-fresh.
content.location: Starts on the right side of the nose on the east side of the Stone Wall Boulder.

content.description:
Sit start on the triangle shaped flake on the left side on the wall. Pull up to slopers and top out, the route is fairly straight forward, but the slopers are really hard, they can actually be described better as a face with shallow rounded indents, to top out with. The slopers will shred the skin off your fingers, so if you can climb with tape on your fingers it may be a good decision, or else some blood may be shed. 

  Way hard for V2
content.location: Four feet left of Quincy Market, on the obvious triangle chalked flake.

content.description:
A fun and powerful route. Sit start on the triangle jug as for Stone Wall and move to the good crimps on the lip and traverse the lip right until you intercept Quincy Market then top out that problem.  

  Very fun route with powerful moves in the middle, if powerful isn't your strong point you can technique through it on slopers.
content.location: On the Stone Wall Boulder start on the jug of Stone Wall and traverse the lip topping out with Quincy Market.

content.description: Sit start in the middle of the "nose" and top out straight up the face after pulling the first awkward moves. The rock that comes out of the ground by the sit start does not count, first move is really awkward, but incredibly fun. For this move use great hands but almost no feet, what must be done is heel hook by your hands with your left foot and use a small flake under the overhang for your right foot and crank hard off the ground to a good hold which is a fairly long move, from here the hard stuff is over, just cruise up the really easy slab to top out.
content.location: East side of the Stone Wall Boulder in the middle of the nose, start on jugs with feet under the "nose".

content.description: Sit start on the ledge and climb straight up, crimpy near top. The start is super easy and the top is also easy, just need a little balance on the large ledge when reaching for the small crimps. Being tall is a distinct advantage, I feel like this route may actually be a grade harder if you are short. The top out is good.
content.location: On the stone wall boulder on the opposite side as the road.

content.description:
Just on the other side of the stone wall as you enter the Pound, there are some jugs to your right, sit start and move up the slightly overhanging face on jugs, when get to the lip where there is a hidden jug just over the lip. So stand on the stone wall before you try it and locate this gem of a hold. Once in this hold move your feet up and reach to the obvious slopey slot, once in this slot move feet up again, then move hands over the top on more slopey holds, with your right hand bump to a good hold about six inches back. At this point you want to have the weight of yourself on your left foot so you can put your right foot into the hidden hold just over the lip. Once in this hold with you right foot the problem is a walk up from there. This is hard because you have to feel the holds for your feet because you cannot see them. 

  I feel this is harder than (vo).  

  Also be sure to have a spotter because of the nature of this route if you cut off at the wrong point you will land on your back and it hurts trust me I have taken this fall. Also have the spotter watch you from hitting the wall to the right, I have seen two people sprain their ankles from awkwardly landing on the wall.
content.protection: Pad and spot so you don't hit the wall.
content.location: just on the other side of the stone wall as you enter the Pound

content.description:
The crux is right at the beginning first two moves then you are good. 

  All the holds are very positive, nothing is bad. 

  Sit start on the little crimp with right hand and left hand on the down slanting crimp just above first hold. Toe hook under the little overhang just off the ground with the other foot back on the little ledge. Heel hook just above toe hook then make the first push up to the crux. Grab the jug and finish the climb up and over the top. 

  The decent. Either climb down the backside of the boulder or climb down backstage passes.
content.location: If you're looking at Backstage Passes walk to the left near the arete right to the left of The Pound sign.

content.description:
Stand Start on crimps and climb the awesome face up and right, the is a hold that looks like a really bad crimp to your left as high as you can reach, is in fact a bomber incut hold, which is a God send at this point, the route is a little harder if instead of breaking right to the jug, break left and top out with the seam, to a crimp then bump to a jug at the top. 

  There is also a sit start, which starts on the feet for the stand start, this is a hard one move added onto it. Myself and others who have done it feel it makes it (V2).
content.location: On the Stone Wall Boulder the face that faces the road, the holds are always chalked.

content.description:
Sit start as for Quincy Market But traverse right after the first move over the stone wall and top out on great holds. The moves over the stone wall are the crux because in your head all you can think about it not cracking your "cranium" off the wall below you. There is a hold with and X on it, just in case you don't know this means that this hold cannot be trusted to hold, it cannot be pulled out but if you have all your weight hanging on it there is potential it could pop out resulting in the dreaded "cranium" crash. 

  This route is named for the potential damage you can do to your cranium if you fall on the wall.
content.protection: Pads and a good spotter for when you are above the stone wall.
content.location: On the Stone Wall Boulder aka the Entrance Boulder, start as for Quincy Market.

content.description: Sit start on the left end of the nose and move up with the arete, I felt this may be easy for the grade, but I not going to say it for certain because every route is different for different people. Not an overly memorable route.
content.location: Start on the east side of the Stone Wall Boulder, follow the arete.

content.description:
The left trending weakness from the middle of the face. This route has plenty of big holds and feet and is a good problem for beginners or for someone who want to do a nice easy route. Also a good warm up because it can become harder, if you eliminate the big holds.  

  This can also be used as a down climb.
content.location: On the Stone Wall Boulder on the face that faces the road.

content.description: This is the boulder that is on your right when you step over the stone wall. There are  lot of problems on this route and the best one in my opinion is Stone Wall (V0+). This is a common place to see beginner boulders because of the amount of high quality easier problems.
